reasoning: Early RSI and 2–3× productivity make 10× domain accelerations plausible, though wet-lab/physical bottlenecks remain.
This is a definition, not a factual outcome; Claim A doesn’t affect whether this is the adopted definition.
A implies fast gains but not instant bypass of physical/data/legal limits, supporting a bottleneck-aware forecast approach.
RSI and productivity gains raise odds of rapid discovery of general-purpose bio tools despite real-world constraints.
Accelerated modeling/design and parallelization are more credible, though human trials/regulatory steps still slow some cases.
Strong acceleration helps, but biology, infrastructure, and clinical constraints make such sweeping outcomes still uncertain.
RSI plus better measurement/intervention and modeling boosts rapid neuro progress; curing most mental illness is still ambitious.
Cheaper, more capable AI improves planning/logistics and lowers costs, aiding distribution if coordination/politics cooperate.
Higher scientific/technical productivity and AI-guided policy make fast growth more feasible, contingent on governance.
Acceleration increases stakes for regime competition, supporting the need for entente-like strategies; neutrality of AI remains plausible.
More capable, cheaper AI makes counter-propaganda, legal transparency, and service delivery improvements more attainable.
RSI and 2–3× productivity point toward rapidly cheaper, better AI, hastening obsolescence of current labor structures.
A directly asserts early takeoff and rapid capability normalization—core to a 'gentle singularity' framing.
Early RSI and current productivity boosts support near-term timelines for insight generation and competent robotics.
Faster capability gains increase ROI on compute/datacenters and automation, reinforcing accelerating economic flywheels.
A is consistent with rapid cost declines and high value of capability gains, though the precise rates are partly orthogonal.
2–3× uplift in knowledge work and RSI make junior-coworker agents at scale substantially more likely.
Abundant intelligence from RSI supports radical capability shifts while daily human experiences could remain familiar.
Acceleration of science and cheaper intelligence aligns with falling prices for many goods and uneven sectoral change.
Faster capability compounding raises urgency and centrality of alignment before/while scaling access.
Acceleration increases the need for adaptive policy and user empowerment to avoid authoritarian misuse.
Rapid AI gains heighten capital–labor imbalances, strengthening the case for broad benefit distribution mechanisms.
RSI plus cheap, replicable AI agents raise the plausibility of individuals commanding vast composite intelligence by ~2035.
